nodes.text: Differences in interference between reading color names and naming ink colors are primarily due to differences in prior training (habit strength) and can be measured and modified by practice
Interference (inhibition) has been extensively studied historically and refers to prior associations impeding new or concurrent responses

Method: Developed novel simultaneous stimuli materials presenting a word naming one color printed in ink of a different color so that word and color stimuli occur together; interference operationalized as increase in response time compared to control forms

Experiment 1 method: Compared reading color-name words printed in conflicting ink colors (RCNd) versus same words printed in black (RCNb); 70 college undergraduates; counterbalanced forms; timed aloud reading with stopwatch

Result (Experiment 1): Reading words printed in conflicting colors increased mean time by 2.3 seconds per 100 items (5.6 percent) compared to black; this small difference was not statistically reliable

Experiment 2 method: Compared naming ink colors when ink presented as colored squares (NC) versus naming ink colors when ink was the print of color-name words that named a different color (NCWd); 100 students; timed aloud naming, errors corrected by rule

Result (Experiment 2): Presence of conflicting word stimuli increased mean naming time from 63.3s to 110.3s per 100 items (47.0s increase, 74.3 percent); effect large, highly reliable and shown in distributions

Claim: Associations linking printed words to the habit 'to read' are stronger and more effective than associations linking color percepts to the habit 'to name color', explaining asymmetrical interference

Experiment 3 method: Practice intervention—32 undergraduates practiced naming ink colors of conflicting printed words (NCWd) across multiple days (daily sessions of 200 reactions), with pre/post tests including NC and RCNd

Result (Experiment 3): Practice on NCWd produced a substantial, typical learning curve (33.9% gain on practiced NCWd), partially reduced interference on NCWd but did not eliminate it, increased variability on NCWd, modest transfer improving NC (13.9% gain), and increased interference (slower) on RCNd; newly developed interference on RCNd decayed rapidly with brief practice

Claim: Practice effects can either increase or decrease intersubject variability depending on task complexity and initial variability; practice on more complex, less practiced tasks increases variability while practice on simpler tasks decreases variability

Conclusion: The asymmetric interference pattern (strong word->color interference, weak color->word interference) is attributable to differential training/habit strength; practice can modify but not fully reverse these asymmetries and can alter group variability

Evidence: Sex differences observed—females named colors faster than males; practice reduced the sex gap, suggesting the sex difference is at least partly due to differential training or experience with colors

Limitation: Samples were mainly college students, colors tested were a specific set (red, blue, green, brown, purple), and measures rely on timed aloud responses with some arbitrary error-correction rules, limiting generality

Method detail/evidence: Procedures included counterbalanced forms, daylight illumination, 10-word practice sample, timing to fifth of a second, error recording and specific correction rule (uncorrected errors adjusted by twice average time), and color vision testing
Assumption: Increases in mean response times when conflicting stimuli are present validly quantify the strength of interference between competing stimulus-response associations
